key_points: More than 850,000 homes and businesses in Louisiana and Mississippi are without power after Hurricane Ida.
Hurricane Ida made landfall near Port Fourchon, Louisiana, as a Category 4 storm.
Ida brought 150 mph winds and weakened into a tropical storm as it moved inland.
The hurricane was fed by warm waters in the Gulf of Mexico, intensifying rapidly.
Satellite imagery shows the storm's impact as it made landfall.
Over 16 inches of rain fell in parts of Louisiana, causing significant flooding.
New Orleans' flood-protection system, enhanced after Hurricane Katrina, prevented catastrophic flooding.
Satellite images before the storm showed Grand Isle, Louisiana, submerged due to heavy rains.
Ida is the ninth named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season.
Officials ordered evacuations along the coast, warning some areas may be uninhabitable for weeks.
